title: History of present illness
content: The patient reports progressive weakness in the right upper extremity, with inability to use the index finger and thumb, and limited ability to spread the fingers. He notes muscle wasting in the right hand, particularly in the thenar and hypothenar muscles and the first dorsal interosseous, as well as in the forearm. He describes a flexion contracture of the ring and small fingers. He denies pain in the affected arm or neck, but acknowledges a history of multiple car accidents, including over 10 rear-end collisions, which he believes contributed to cumulative spinal damage. He has no leg weakness or pain. He has not been taking medications for pain. He reports that he can no longer touch the affected side as he could previously and notes that the right side is significantly weaker compared to the left, which remains normal. He has a scheduled EMG for November 4th, but the doctor recommends proceeding with surgery without waiting for the test.

title: Imaging
content: - X-ray: Shows wear and tear in the cervical spine with mild kyphotic posture, disc space narrowing at C4–C5 and C5–C6, moderate disease at C4–C5, severe at C5–C6, and bone spurring at C4–C5 and C5–C6.

- MRI: Reveals severe central stenosis at C5–C6 with severe myomalacia (bruising) and loss of white matter protection. A large disc herniation at C3–C4 is compressing the spinal cord anteriorly with associated myomalacia. There is severe stenosis at C5–C6, moderate to severe at C4–C5 and C6–C7, and moderate stenosis at C7–T1. The spinal cord is compressed and appears flattened, with bright signal changes indicating edema and damage. Exit ramps are narrowed bilaterally, more severely on the left at C5–C6.

title: Plan
content: Recommend surgical intervention for cervical stenosis.
Proceed with anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF) from C3 to C7, possibly extending to C7–T1.
If the fifth level (C7–T1) cannot be accessed from the front, schedule a posterior single-level laminectomy the following day.
Order EMG for nerve conduction study to assess peripheral nerve function.
Refer to Dr. Britton or Dr. Perino for earlier EMG appointment.
Patient to consider surgery within one to two months.
Post-op: Wear cervical collar for six weeks, avoid neck motion, ambulate immediately after surgery.
